item.name: Arkham Horror: The Card Game â€“ The Dunwich Legacy: Expansion
Barrage
item.comment: Fantastic game with really interesting decisions. The overall system of how the water flows down and the way your buildings interact is fantastic. A real brain burner that had me wanting to start a new game before the first one was finished. My personal mark of a fantastic game.

item.name: Brick & Mortar
item.comment:
This game is fantastic. Played it at Kingdomcon twice. Once at 2 players and once at 4 players. At 2 it's more of a race with most of the interaction being to dodge each others product types while at 4 players interaction is unavoidable so you get more of a feel that you're trying to carve out a strong presence in an underrepresented niche.
Can't wait for this to come out.

item.name: Bus
item.comment:
This is a very good game. The fact that it came out in 1999 blows my mind. When I showed my friends this game (capstone version) they were like "this game has a great twist on worker placement" ... the reality is this game may just be the invention of the mechanism.
The only downside for some might be how competitive the game can get and how you can screw others over. To me some action spots feel a bit like a game of chicken.
Never leaving my collection and consider this one of 6 must have splotter titles.

item.name: Cannes: Stars, Scripts and Screens
item.comment:
Cannes is an interesting game. Being from Splotter Spellen you expect it to be a lot heavier than it is. You also expect it to be older as it feels like it predates Bus and Roads & Boats, perhaps even serving as their inspiration. Yet it was released after.
The game itself is quick to learn and quick to play. Cannes also puts a unique spin on the network building and goods processing found other Splotter fare.
Your personal network is a maximum of 5 and must be contiguous, but can be shifted and moved over time. As it lurches along it can connect to the shared 'old boys' network or various multi-hex party tiles.
This is a sharp contrast to the static and ever-growing networks in Roads & Boat and Bus. There is also an interesting shift in the goods processing from Roads & Boats via a limited warehousing of items between rounds that minimizes the fiddly tile piles seen there.
These ideas have potential. The main issue is I don't feel that potential was fully realized here. Where most Splotter Games feel very tight and well developed, Cannes leaves me wanting more from it.
The nail in the coffin for this title is the art and theme. While trying to be whimsical and fun, the theme has not aged well and at times actively pushes you away. The current design with a better theme, a little additional development and improved production would easily have been a great title in the 60 minute genre. As it is there are too many other great games competing for the time slot and weight level where I'd be choosing this game.

item.name: The Castles of Burgundy
item.comment: Very good game. Great at 2. Highly recommend the geek up bags from the bgg store.

item.name: Chronicles of Crime
item.comment: Great crime game with excellent technology integration.

item.name: Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game
Descent: Journeys in the Dark (Second Edition)
Die DolmengÃ¶tter
item.comment: Die DolmengÃ¶tter is a pretty good game. It's easy to learn, fast and presents some interesting decisions in the area majority space. In my one play the game the puzzle Die DolmengÃ¶tter presents felt a little shallow. The speed of the game forgives this a lot however. I'd always be happy to pull this out as a filler but cannot see myself ever looking forward to getting it to the table like some other abstracts that take a similar amount of time.

item.name: A Game of Thrones: The Board Game (Second Edition)
The Great Zimbabwe
item.comment:
This is a really great game. The initial rules are quite easy but the games complexity and tracking logistics over the course of the game can feel a bit tedious. Especially for new players. To me its on the lighter end of splotter but for some reason this resource tracking trips up the players I thought would be best to play this game with.
Overall it is a great game but its simple ruleset doesn't mean you can play it with lighter games players. The tedium of the route checking is the only reason its a 9 instead of 10.

item.name: Indonesia
item.comment:
I've owned this for a while now (since maybe January) but only finally got it to the table. Holy cow is it good. We did mess up a couple of rules that made it longer than it should have been and impacted some of the endgame but overall I really enjoyed it.
The game is long but fully engaging the entire time. Its a solid economic game that has a big focus on being able to analyze the current game state and adapt. I did not intend to go into shipping in my game however I had built a lot of wealth with production and I saw an opportunity to use that to steal control of the biggest shipping lines in the game. This huge cost was paid off over the next few rounds.
Also if you like auction games this is one of the best. The merger auctions are super intense. I believe this is because there are so few assets in play and when a merger occurs it is consolidating those into even fewer. So the value of the merged company is high, but you don't want to get stuck overpaying.
Can't wait to play this one more.

item.name: Legendary Encounters: An Alien Deck Building Game
Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game
Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game â€“ Guardians of the Galaxy
Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game â€“ Secret Wars, Volume 1
Magic Realm
item.comment:
Magic Realm is a very systemic, open-world, sandbox RPG framework. When you play it it feels kind of like an early 90's computer RPG...consider that it released in 1979, 1 year before the titular RPG 'Rogue' was released in 1980. Had I found this in '93 when I was ~10 you would have not been able to stop me obsessing over it. That being said you do feel it's age.
It's inspirational as a designer because of the delta between what promises it evokes and what is fully delivered. The combat is a bit fiddly and the randomness is all input randomness with little to no mitigation. (Almost all checks are roll 2d6 use the higher number...high numbers are bad).
I can't help but look at it in all it's imperfection and still love it. I've had an open world sandbox rpg idea in my head for some time and this game 100% delivered an experience that showed me it's not only possible to make but it's also worth doing.
Mix in that the game can theoretically support up to 16 players and has a solid PVP system. Most modern RPG board games are co-op. Magic Realms lets you cooperate or compete. You can pay me for knowledge of shortcuts and treasure locations, or kill me and loot my corpse, if you can kill me...
Worth a play if you're into simulationist open world games and enjoy emergent narrative i.e. you can smile and enjoy a couple of bad rolls that kill you. The game does feature the ability to make a new character and rejoin, the progression is not experienced based so you're not as far behind as you might think, and person in first can hit a string of bad luck and wipe as easily as you just did.

item.name: Oraklos
item.comment: This game was cute. Very random, almost party ish game. I could see it being fun with kids. Glad I played it once. Nothing particularly special.

item.name: Pax Pamir: Second Edition
item.comment: Played my first proper game of this and it is sublime.

item.name: Planet Steam
item.comment:
Fine for a single play this game was just not good. On the surface the game has some interesting ideas. An economic focused resource collection game with a volatile and shifting market. The most interesting part of the game should be the market, and it is. The problem is the market isn't very interesting. With only 5 rounds in a game about market change you don't really get much time to see things truly rise and fall. You have no time to leverage a good bought cheaply for a later profit.
I understand why the game has so few rounds however, producing goods. The best part of the goods production is the modular minis which is kind of cool but doesn't really serve the game. The puzzle itself is positional and able to be fully reset each round which provides too many options. This increases the decision space and thus the time spent in the round, instead of the market which is where we should be.
Ultimately this game suffered, like many euro games, trying to be a bit too much of everything and taking way to long to do it all. Having market analysis, puzzle based resource generation and way too many auctions ends up diluting the focus of the game.
A mediocre 30 minute game with a strong theme is one thing but 3 hours of mediocrity is never ok.

item.name: Pueblo
item.comment:
Pueblo is great. It's easy to learn and fun, though it can be quite intense and mean in the right group of players. As a 3D abstract it utilizes the dimensionality in a meaningful way. The only issue I have with the game is that I can see the core puzzle of this game wearing thin after enough plays.
A great game to have if you like abstracts and rotate through them enough.

item.name: Roads & Boats
item.comment:
Only a few plays in so far but it is one of my favorite games. One of the most epic board games out there and it comes with a rather simple ruleset. It's a fantastic game that I can't wait to get the table as often as possible.
Luckily it has a great single player puzzle mode.

item.name: Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island
SCOUT
item.comment:
This game is fantastic. Having grown up on card games like Gin and Rummy it really plays to my preferences. It hits all aspects of a good card game. Light rules, round based play, great use of rank order and hand management.
I initially played a pnp version and thought the theme was a bit too pasted on and the colors quite loud. However after having played several times with the official version I must say it's grown on me and have come to appreciate the production.
The care and love for this game is apparent in the little touches that Oink! put in. Splaying a large run and seeing the rainbow gradation in the splay is quite pleasing. This gradation and the chunky blocks of color when sets match in your hand work well to provide the player with a very quick visual heuristic of the power of their hand.
In the end Oink created a dramatic production that starts out feeling garish but over time reveals the subtlety to the UX design. Fantastic game.

item.name: Scythe
item.comment: Played but don't own

item.name: Teotihuacan: City of Gods
item.comment:
Got to play this for the first time last night. I love complex and deep games and this is certainly that. Very rarely when I sit down and learn a game do I get a sense of being lost. That is how I felt at first diving into that. I don't say that as a negative. I thoroughly enjoyed analyzing the systems and trying to figure out what was optimal.
In the end i came in last but can't wait to play again.

item.name: Through the Ages: A New Story of Civilization
item.comment: Fantastic game that is worth the long play time. Gives a sense of 7 wonders but a better experience.

item.name: Townsfolk Tussle
item.comment:
Played on TTS to see if I want to back. It's definitely fun. But this is not a game I want to pay a high dollar for detailed minis on. If the game was half the price with cardboard standees I'd probably get it.
Overall the game feels quite light and has a bit more randomness than any real planning.
Played with 3 players and found it a bit easy for a co-op game. None of us were ever knocked out in the game.
The loot system on bosses feels a bit off as well. This is because many of the feats felt very random if you could fulfill. In our game one player got several easier to achieve feats where me and the other player got much more difficult ones. The 1 time we tied him on feats he wont the roll off so he ended up being the only one with boss gear.
If you like a random experience and prefer seeing what happens vs strategy / planning towards it then this game will be a hit.
The art is fantastic, the game flow is quite smooth and its easy to pick up. I would absolutely play this again with the right groups but it doesn't have a place in my personal collection.

item.name: Viticulture Essential Edition
item.comment: Pretty good but not my favorite worker placement.
